heading: 'nature' snatches genome map?
subheading: a strand of controversy has emerged over celera's publication arrangement with the journal for the company's human genome map. the deal has caused human genome project researchers to seek an alternative home for their map. by kristen philipkoski.
author: wired staff
text: rumors of where the human genome project's groundbreaking research paper will wind up are flying faster than rna messages. earlier this week, the word on the street was the paper from the government-funded consortium would be submitted to the journal science for simultaneous publication with research from celera genomics, a for-profit company that created its own human genome map.now hgp officials say that's definitely not happening, and more than likely their paper will go to the journal nature -- if only because the human genome project leaders were miffed by a recent agreement between celera and science.there are other scientific journals, but none with the cachet of the above-mentioned two."the issue doesn't have anything to do with celera, it has to do with science and the fact that we just disagree with data restrictions," said john mcpherson, co-director of the genome sequencing center at washington university in st. louis, missouri. mcpherson is the lead author on one of about 10 papers in total he confirmed have now been submitted to an unidentified journal based on the hgp research.the special arrangement with science would allow the company to monitor access to its database of gene information by hosting it on the celera website.the agreement is unusual because gene researchers in the past have typically submitted their data to genbank, a free, government-funded database.some scientists are worried that the move could set a precedent that would limit scientific progress, because it's a departure from providing unrestricted data for other scientists to use and replicate.as a result, hgp researchers are choosing not to submit to science what many think is the most important science since james watson and francis crick described the structure of dna in nature in 1953.one source who asked not to be identified said that instead of science the research will be submitted to nature, but a spokeswoman at the national human genome research institute, the main organization overseeing the hgp, said the researchers would rather stick with custom and wait until publication to make any announcements."we will continue on the path of not disclosing where we've submitted, because that's good old tradition in scientific publishing," said nhgri spokeswoman kathy hudson.researchers traditionally wait until the publication date to disclose the specifics of when and where, the reason being that after submission, a paper must go through a rigorous peer-review process and publication is not guaranteed.celera officials dispensed with that tradition by announcing in a press release last week that they had submitted their paper to science.in june, the rival genome mapping teams surprised the scientific community by ending an ongoing race to finish the maps, and announcing together that they each had completed a "working draft." at the time they suggested a dual publication would happen by the end of the year.
